summary.value: In the present project, we investigate the role of the historical context for retirement adjustment, using a nationally representative German cohort-sequential survey, the German Ageing Survey (DEAS). We distinguish developments for white-collar and blue-collar workers and investigate if historical differences in adjustment can be explained by social resources and voluntariness of retirement.

summary.value:
Participating Authors:
C. Evers (c.evers@uu.nl) Utrecht University
A. Kip (a.kip@uvt.nl) Utrecht University /Tilburg university
J.F.IJbema (J.F.Ybema@uu.nl) Utrecht University

1. Have any data been collected for this study already?
Moment of registration: Registration after data cleaning, but before any main analyses of the existing dataset.  
We consider this a registration for a secondary analyses plan that is exploratory in nature. 
The data were previously collected by A. Kip during a master thesis project 2018-2019 at Utrecht University. The existing dataset, codebook, data collection procedure and prior work based on the dataset can be found on: https://osf.io/9yzn7/

2.What's the main question being asked or hypothesis being tested in this study? (optional)

The main question within the present research is whether and to what extent emotions are used as a license for eating behavior in daily life, and what personal and/or demographical factors play a (underlying) role? 
Question 1) Is there a relationship between the intensity of experienced emotions prior to eating and the extent to which emotions are used as a justification to eat, and how is this relationship influenced by trait characteristics of restrained eating or emotional eating. 

Emotions and emotional justifications (eating during snack moments) 
1. Cross-level two way interaction:
We expect that the intensity of positive emotions prior to eating (POS_EMO_WM) shows a (small) positive relationship with the extent to which positive emotions were used as justifications to eat (LIC_POS_EMO_WM) at the level of snack moment,
this relationship will be stronger for those who (a) score high on restrained eating (RE-scale) or (B) emotional eating (SEES-subscale positive) at the person level. 

2. Cross-level two way interaction:
We expect that the intensity of negative emotions prior to eating (NEG_EMO_WM) shows a  (small) positive relationship with the extent to which negative emotions were used as justifications to eat (LIC_NEG_EMO_WM) at the level of snack moment, 
this relationship will be stronger for those who (a) score high on restrained eating (RE-scale) or (B) emotional eating (SEES-subscale negative) at the person level. 

Question 2:  Whether and to what extent are emotions used as a license for eating behavior in terms of caloric intake, and how is this relationship influenced by trait characteristics of restrained eating or emotional eating.

3. Cross-level two way interaction (within all snack moments):
We expect that licensing (Licensing_1) shows a (small) positive relationship with caloric intake (KCAL) at the level of snack moment, 
this relationship will be stronger for those who score high on restrained eating (RE-scale) at the person level. 

4 . Cross-level two way interaction (within all snack moments):
We expect that the use of positive emotional justifications (LIC_POS_EMO_WM) shows 
a (small) positive relationship with caloric intake (KCAL) at the level of snack moment, 
this relationship will be stronger for those who score high on restrained eating (RE-
 scale) or emotional eating (SEES-subscale positive) at the person level. 

5.	Cross-level two way interaction (within all snack moments):
We expect that the use of negative emotional justifications (LIC_NEG_EMO_WM) shows a (small) positive relationship with caloric intake (KCAL) at the level of snack moment, 
this relationship will be stronger for those who score high on restrained eating (RE-scale) or emotional eating (SEES-subscale negative) at the person level.

6.	Cross-level three way interaction (for snack moments after emotion registration):
We expect a (small) positive relationship between positive emotions prior to eating (POS_EMO_WM) and caloric intake (KCAL), this relationship will be stronger when licensing (Licensing_1) was high compared to when licensing was low, at the level of snack moment,
this interaction effect will be stronger for those who score high on restrained eating (RE-scale) or emotional eating (SEES-subscale positive) at the person level. 

7.	Cross-level three way interaction (for snack moments after emotion registration):
We expect a (small) positive relationship between negative emotions prior to eating (NEG_EMO_WM) and caloric intake (KCAL), this relationship will be stronger when licensing (Licensing_1) was high compared to when licensing was low, at the level of snack moment,
this interaction effect will be stronger for those who score high on restrained eating (RE-scale) or emotional eating (SEES-subscale negative) at the person level. 

3.	Describe the key dependent variable(s) specifying how they will be measured. (optional)
Dependent variable: caloric intake during snack moments. If participants registered an eating moment “at night” or an “other moment”, they registered the specific product(s) they ate and the amount (FREQ) they ate of each selected product. For each of these Snack moments, participants could register up to 10 different products (577-item list). Per snacking moment, the total amount of calories was computed by adding the caloric values (recodedvalues) of each product(PRODUCT) times its amount (FREQ).

(e.g. A1_PRODUCT(recodedvalue)*A1_FREQ +  A2_PRODUCT(recodedvalue)*A2_FREQ  + …etc.) Also see Codebook sheet Products for recoded values (kcal).


4.	How many and which conditions will participants be assigned to? (optional)
N/A

5.	Specify exactly which analyses you will conduct to examine the main question/hypothesis. (optional)

 	List predictors included in hypotheses: 
-Weighted mean of the intensity of experienced positive emotions prior to eating (POS_EMO_WM)
 -Weighted mean of the intensity of experienced negative emotions prior to eating (NEG_EMO_WM) 
-Weighted mean of the extent to which positive emotions were used as a justification to eat (LIC_ POS_EMO_WM)
-Weighted mean of the extent to which negative emotions were used as a justification to (LIC_NEG_EMO_WM) 
- The degree to which justifications were used to eat (i.e. licensing) (Licensing_1) 
- SEES-subscales for positive and negative emotional eating (Meule, Reichenberger & Blechert, 2018) 
-RE-scale for restrained eating (Herman & Polivy, 1980)

Data transformation:
Predictors on the person level will be centered around the grand mean (GMC), whereas predictors on the level of the snack moment will be centered around the person mean (PMC). Predictors with substantial variation at both levels, will be split into a person level variable (GMC) and a within person variable (PMC). A LOG (log e) transformation will be used if the dependent variable caloric intake (KCAL) is highly skewed.  

After data transformation, all analyses will initially be performed including any remaining outliers on the dependent measures of caloric intake (KCAL). Additional analyses excluding outliers on caloric intake will be performed and will be reported if these additional results are inconsistent.  

The intensity of experienced positive emotions and negative emotions:
We will first analyze a new dichotomous variable (i.e. experienced positive (or negative) emotions: yes / no).  
Second, we will analyze only the subset in which positive (or negative) emotions were experienced (yes) and their magnitude on a scale from 0 (not at all) to 100 (Very much) (POS_EMO_WM and NEG_EMO_WM). 

The extent to which positive emotions and negative emotions were used as justifications to eat: 
We will first analyze a new dichotomous variable (i.e. positive (or negative) emotions used as justification to eat: yes / no).  
Second, we will analyze only the subset in which positive (or negative) emotions were used as a justification to eat (yes) and their magnitude on a scale from 0 (not at all) to 100 (very much) (LIC_ POS_EMO_WM and LIC_ NEG_EMO_WM). 


Statistical models:
For continuous outcome variables we will perform a hierarchical multilevel regression in SPSS, using the Linear Mixed Models program with Maximum Likelihood estimation. For dichotomous outcome variables (and highly skewed continuous outcome variables), a hierarchical multilevel regression in R will be performed, using the LME4-package, with the GLMER-procedure using Maximum Likelihood estimation (Laplace Approximation). 

The hypotheses include cross-level two way and three way interactions: 
Predictors on the person level will be centered around the grand mean (GMC), whereas predictors on the level of the snack moment will be centered around the person mean (PMC). Predictors with substantial variation at both levels, will be split into a person level variable (GMC) and a within person variable (PMC). 

Competing models will be tested using the deviance test (-2 log likelihood) to determine the improvement of fit by entering additional predictors in the model. If the deviance test proves significant (alpha-level = .05), individual regression weights will be tested (alpha-level = .05, two-tailed tests).

Statistical Analysis Backup Plan: 
For highly skewed continuous outcome variables, a hierarchical multilevel regression in R will be performed, using the LME4-package, with the GLMER-procedure using Maximum Likelihood estimation, and a lognormal distribution. 

Inference criteria:
If the deviance test proves significant (alpha-level = .05), individual regression weights will be tested (alpha-level = .05, two-tailed tests).

6.	Any secondary analyses? (optional)
See 8. for additional information. 

7.	How many observations will be collected or what will determine the sample size? No need to justify decision, but be precise about exactly how the number will be determined. (optional)

The collected data set has participants N =186 (Screening), N = 181 (Step 1 Information), N = 165 (Step 3 Exit Survey), 3623 registered Eating Moments (Stap 2 Eating) and 5395 registered experienced emotions (Stap 2 Mood). 

At this moment, there is no consensus regarding the requirements to conduct power analyses for the multilevel analyses that are considered for the present research. 

A power calculation based on linear mixed effects simulation in R (5000 iterations) showed that a sample of 120 will have sufficient power at the level of the on the level of the snack moment (0.89) and person level (0.80) to detect a small interaction effect between (positive /negative) emotions experienced prior to eating (β = 0.06) and licensing (β = 0.15), on caloric intake (KCAL) at an alpha of 0.05. Assuming an interclass correlation coefficient (ICC) of 0.30 and on average, a b-weight of 0.015 for restrained eating at the person level and 15 snack moments per participants. 


8.	Anything else you would like to pre-register? (e.g., data exclusions, variables collected for exploratory purposes, unusual analyses planned?) (optional)

Prior research activity (see prior work: https://osf.io/9yzn7/):
The following demographics and sample characteristics were previously assessed for descriptive purposes . 
- Body Mass Index (SC_BMI). Body mass index was calculated based on reported current weight (Q39) and height (Q38). 
- Goal motivation (scale: GOAL_5, GOAL_6, GOAL_7, GOAL_8, GOAL_9). Participants rated the motivation to achieve their goal to lose or maintain weight, all items were scored on scales ranging from 0 (not at all) to 100 (very much).  
- Eating concerns. Three items were used to assess overall eating concerns (Prinsen, Evers, & De Ridder, 2016): “Do you watch your weight?”, “Do you watch what you eat in order to lose weight or to not gain weight?”, and ”Do you watch what you eat for your general health?”. Items were scored on scales ranging from 0 (not at all) to 100 (very much). 
- Diet goal (SC_GOAL),
- Gender (geslacht)
- Age (END_Age), 
- Education (edu) 

The following measures were previously assessed with single items on scales ranging from 0 (not at all) to 100 (very much), based on the variables collected for each eating occasion (see codebook: sheet Stap 2 Eetpatroon (eating)). 
- Self-licensing: “To what degree did you just use a justification to eat/drink?” (Licensing_1). 
- Temptation motivation: “How strongly did you desire what you just ate/drank?” (MOT_TEMP_1). 
- Goal motivation: “How important was your goal to lose- or maintain weight when you were just about to eat/drink?” (MOT_GOAL_1). 
- To assess the relative balance between competing motivations we calculated difference scores similar to Studies 1 and 2 by subtracting goal motivation (MOT_GOAL_1) from temptation motivation (MOT_TEMP_1). 
- Experienced food intake: "How much did you just eat/drink?" (SUB_intake_1) on a scale of 0 (too little) to 100 (too much).  

Data Inclusion/exclusion: 
We will use data from the following datasets: Screening, Step 1 Information, Step 3 Exit Survey as well the collected data on eating (Step 2 Eating) and emotions (Stap 2 Mood). 
All participants who have complete data for the datasets: Screening, Step 1 Information and Step 3 Exit Survey will be included. 

Linking emotions (Stap 2 Stemming) to snack moment (Stap 2 Eetpatroon): 
- We will only include snack moments which were preceded by registration of experienced emotions. We will link the registered experienced emotions to a snack moment in the following way: 
- Each snack moment will be linked to the last emotional experience that was registered prior to that eating occasion in time. 
-Only snack moments that are registered within 180 minutes following the last emotion measurement are included.
- The registered emotional experience will only be linked to a single snack moment. In other words, if registration of experienced emotions is followed by registration of two or more subsequent eating occasions, we will only include the first eating occasion. 
- Each morning 06:00 is a new starting point. 


Missing data:
Any rows including missing datapoints on a specific variable will be excluded from analyses including that variable. 
For example, we already anticipate that there will be missing values for certain food products. If participants could not indicate a food product in the provided product list (see Codebook: sheet products) they could choose the option “Overig /Other”. In this case, there is a missing value (9999) for any one of the PRODUCT variables (A1 to A10) that are included for the dependent variable caloric intake (KCAL).  All rows including missing data on KCAL will be excluded from analyses.

Exploratory analyses:

We will explore the possible contribution of demographical characteristics to the describe confirmatory analyses: 
Sex (geslacht), ethnicity (ethnic), Income (Inkomen), Age (END_AGE), Body Mass Index (EXIT_BMI) and/or exercise behavior (Exercise_min). 

We will repeat the confirmatory analyses as exploratory analyses at the level of meals instead of snack moment, including only breakfast, lunch, dinner. 

We will explore any possible correlations and/or interactions at the level of snack moment (excluding breakfast, lunch, dinner) OR at the level of meals (including breakfast, lunch, dinner): 

Between licensing (Licensing_1), OR positive emotional justifications to eat (LIC_POS_EMO_WM), OR negative emotional justifications to eat (LIC_NEG_EMO_WM), positive emotions, OR positive emotions prior to eating (POS_EMO_WM) , OR negative emotions prior to eating (NEG_EMO_WM)  on the one hand (IV’s), 
AND perceived food intake (SUB_intake_1) restrained eating (RESTR_EAT_1), guilt (GUILT_1) on the other hand (DV’s). 

 And in turn, we will explore any possible cross-level correlations OR interactions at the 
 person level based on restrained eating (RE-scale), emotional eating (SEES subscale 
 positive or negative), emotion regulation (ERQ-scale), Trait Self-Control (SC-scale).

We will explore any possible correlations and/or interactions at the level of snack moment (excluding breakfast, lunch, dinner) OR at the level of meals (including breakfast, lunch, dinner): 

Between licensing (Licensing_1), OR positive emotional justifications to eat (LIC_POS_EMO_WM), OR negative emotional justifications to eat (LIC_NEG_EMO_WM), positive emotions, OR positive emotions prior to eating (POS_EMO_WM) , OR negative emotions prior to eating (NEG_EMO_WM)  on the one hand (IV’s), 
AND perceived food intake (SUB_intake_1) restrained eating (RESTR_EAT_1), guilt (GUILT_1) on the other hand (DV’s). 

 And in turn, we will explore any possible cross-level correlations OR interactions at the 
 person level based on restrained eating (RE-scale), emotional eating (SEES subscale 
 positive or negative), emotion regulation (ERQ-scale), Trait Self-Control (SC-scale).

attributes.title: The effectiveness of Peyton’s 4-step teaching approach on skill acquisition of procedures in health professions education: a systematic review and meta-analysis

summary.value:
PROTOCOL FOR A SYSTEMACTIC REVIEW
The effectiveness of Peyton’s 4-step teaching approach on skill acquisition of procedures in health professions education: a protocol for a systematic review and meta-analysis.

BACKGROUND
Acquisition of procedures is an important element in health professions education. Traditionally procedures are taught using the “see one - do one” approach. That is a teacher demonstrates and describes a procedure and afterwards the students practice the procedure. A more recent teaching approach was presented by Peyton (1998). Peyton’s approach consists of four steps. Step 1 refers to the demonstration of the procedure in real time; within step 2 the teacher demonstrates the procedure and describes each procedural sub-step; the student talks the trainer through in step 3 and in step 4 the students performs the procedure.

REVIEW QUESTION
To evaluate the effectiveness of Peyton’s 4 step teaching method on the acquisition of procedural skills in health professions education.

SEARCHES
We will search the following electronic databases for eligible studies: Medline via OVID, PsycInfo, Embase and ERIC. There will be no restrictions regarding recency or publication language. The search strategy will be build using two blocks. The first block will consist of terms relevant for the identification of the population (i.e. students in health professions education). We will search for keywords and map the keywords to relevant subject headings. The second block will be designed to identify studies using Peyton’s teaching approach.

The following search strategy will be used in Medline:
#	Searches
1	schools, medical.mp. or Schools, Medical/
2	schools, nursing.mp. or Schools, Nursing/
3	schools, health occupations.mp. or Schools, Health Occupations/
4	education, professional.mp. or Education, Professional/
5	education medical.mp. or Education, Medical/
6	education pharmacy.mp. or Education, Pharmacy/
7	education dental.mp. or Education, Dental/
8	Physical Therapy Modalities/ or education physiotherapy.mp.
9	1 or 2 or 3 or 4 or 5 or 6 or 7 or 8
10	Peyton.mp.
11	4 step.mp.
12	four step.mp.
13	deconstructive teaching.mp.
14	see one do one teach one.mp.
15	see one do one.mp.
16	Peyton four-step.mp.
17	Peytons four-step.mp.
18	10 or 11 or 12 or 13 or 14 or 15 or 16 or 17
19	resident*.mp.
20	student*.mp.
21	traine*.mp.
22	19 or 20 or 21
23	9 or 22
24	18 and 23

The search strategy will be amended to meet the requirements of the other databases.

TYPES OF STUDIES TO BE INCLUDED
Randomised controlled trials will be included. Cross over studies will be eligible as well presumed that sufficient data is available. 

CONDITION OR DOMAIN BEING STUDIED
Acquisition of procedural skills in health professions education. 

PARTICIPANTS
We will include studies reporting about students in health professions education. Health professions education is used as an umbrella term for medical and allied health profession education. We will include studies reporting about pre-graduate and postgraduate students.

INTERVENTIONS
Studies need to investigate Peyton’s four-step approach.

COMPARATOR
Studies need to have a comparator group. The comparator can be a specific educational intervention, educational practice a usual or a sham intervention.

MAIN OUTCOME
The primary outcome for this review will be the evaluation of procedural skills. These can be evaluated using a procedure specific checklist or a global rating scale. To be included studies have to report on this outcome.

ADDITONAL OUTCOMES
The secondary outcome will be the time needed to perform the procedure.

STUDY SELECTION
Records will be screened by two independent reviewers. Disagreements will be solved by discussion. 

DATA EXTRACTION
Two reviewers will independently extract relevant data into an electronic database.

RISK OF BIAS ASSESSMENT
The risk of bias will be evaluated with the Cochrane risk of bias tool. A human reviewer will evaluate all included studies. Evaluations will be compared against a machine learning classification of the risk of bias with the application “RobotReviewer” (Marshall et al., 2015). Disagreements will be solved by discussion with a third person.

STRATEGY FOR DATA SYNTHESIS
The primary endpoint for the evaluation of the effectiveness of the comparisons will be at the end of the intervention. A secondary analysis will be performed using data from the longest available follow up endpoint.
Data analysis
The analysis will be performed using the statistical software package R. A meta-analysis of pairwise comparisons will be performed using the meta package (Schwarzer, 2007). A random effects model will be used for the analysis and effectiveness will be reported using standardized effect sizes (hedges’ g) and corresponding 95% confidence intervals. Effect sizes will be interpreted following Cohen (1992). Statistical heterogeneity will be assessed with I2 statistic using the guidelines presented in the Cochrane handbook for systematic reviews of interventions (Higgins and Green, 2011). If possible, we will perform a meta-regression and potential moderator variables such as the student teach ratio will be explored.

REFERENCES
COHEN, J. 1992. A power primer. Psychological bulletin, 112, 155.
HIGGINS, J. P. & GREEN, S. 2011. Cochrane handbook for systematic reviews of interventions, John Wiley & Sons.
MARSHALL, I. J., KUIPER, J. & WALLACE, B. C. 2015. RobotReviewer: evaluation of a system for automatically assessing bias in clinical trials. Journal of the American Medical Informatics Association, 23, 193-201.
PEYTON, J. 1998. Teaching in the theatre. In: PEYTON, J. (ed.) Teaching and learning in medical practice. UK: Manticore Europe.
SCHWARZER, G. 2007. meta: An R package for meta-analysis. R news, 7, 40-45.

attributes.title: The Interplay of Interval Models and Entrainment Models in Duration Perception Experiment 2

q1.value: The Interplay of Interval Models and Entrainment Models in Duration Perception

q3.value: Entrainment has been proposed to be essential to listeners’ estimates of short time durations and prediction of onset timings. One of the most influential proposals is McAuley and Jones’ framework (2003). They demonstrated that listeners’ duration estimates were shifted from reality in opposite directions when to-be-judged durations occurred earlier than an entrained beat vs. later than an entrained beat, which is predicted by their entrainment models. However, neither their model nor the previous studies specify how long the entrainment persists after the cessation of external stimulation. We plan to explore entrainment decay in a duration estimation task which has 300 ms context tones with short (600 ms; 2 beats), medium (1200 ms; 4 beats) and long (2400 ms; 8 beats) delay versions. We have two goals in the current study. First, we want to test the persistence of the entrainment effect by observing the behavioral patterns across three designed delay lengths. Second, we plan to test different hypotheses of entrainment decrease by manipulating three delay lengths and compare it to our previous experiment, which had two absolute delay matches (1200 and 2400 ms) and two relative delay matches (2 beats and 4 beats).

q4.value: If the entrainment effect persists for more than a few beats, as suggested by McAuley and Jones’ framework, we should observe the same response pattern across different delay lengths. If the entrainment effect decreases across time, we will not observe the pattern in the longer-delay length condition. Moreover, comparing the results of the current experiment to our previous experiment allows us to test whether entrainment decreases after a certain amount of time (absolute delay) vs. a certain number of beats (relative delay). Our previous experiment had 600 ms inter-tone intervals and delays of 1.2 s (2 beats) and 2.4 s (4 beats). If the absolute delay account is true, we should observe entrainment decreases between 1.2 s and 2.4 s, as found in our previous experiment. If the relative delay account is true, we should observe entrainment decreases between 0.6 (2 beats) and 1.2 s (4 beats).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: A within-subject 3 (Delay Length) × 3 (Comparison Onset) × 6 (Comparison Duration) repeated measures design will be used in this study. Short-delay, medium-delay and long-delay trials will be blocked and fully counterbalanced. To carefully control the response bias of responding by their dominant hand, we also plan to counterbalance the response keys across participants (half of participants responded F key as shorter, J key as longer; the other half, J key as shorter, F key as longer).

q9.value: We will randomize the presenting order of trials for each participant within each block.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through the SONA website. Participants will receive 2 credits for agreeing to participate. Participants must be at least 18 years old.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 48 participants. We will attempt to recruit more until the sample size meets our target sample size.

q14.value: The effects we planned to detect are the effect of comparison onset time (early, on-time, late relative to an expected beat) and the interaction of onset time and delay length. The effect of comparison onset time is crucial for verifying that entrainment effects are present at short delays. The interaction term is crucial for determining if there is a decrease in entrainment at the longer delay. We estimated a moderate effect size of h2p = .1. With this effect size, G*Power (Faul et al., 2007) indicates a sample size of 46 or higher is needed to achieve power of .80. We rounded this up slightly to 48 to reach a multiple of 4, given two block orders and two response key assignments. This criterion was used in our original study, so we maintain this criterion here.

q15.value: We plan to collect 48 participants. In the original experiment, we found that some participants showed aberrant points of subjective equality, which appeared to result from very low accuracy even on the easiest (shortest and longest) stimuli. In that study, we eliminated participants who scored below 60% accuracy on those “easy” trials in either or both blocks. We maintain this criterion in the current study, now as an a priori exclusion criterion. These low-accuracy participants will be replaced. Past this number, any additional participant subject-pool sign-ups will be tested for their own educational benefit, but their data will not be analyzed.

question.value: We have three independent variables. First, Delay Length with three levels: short, medium and long delay length. Second, Comparison Onset with three levels: early, ontime and late onset. Third, Comparison Duration with six levels: 275 ms, 285 ms, 295 ms, 305 ms, 315 ms, 325 ms.

We plan to measure participants’ trial-by-trial responses (i.e. shorter or longer), reaction time and their music backgrounds. Trial-by-trial responses are converted into three dependent variables: proportion short; proportion correct; point of subjective equality.

We will use two-way within-subject 3 (Delay Length) × 3 (Comparison Onset) repeated measures ANOVAs to analyze the results of each of the three dependent variables: proportion short; proportion correct; point of subjective equality. As in McAuley and Jones (2003) and in our earlier experiment, we collapse over the factor Comparison Duration. Bonferroni-corrected t-tests will be used to discern the nature of any significant effects.

For each DV, we expect a Delay Length x Comparison Onset interaction. 
1. At shortest delay length, effect of Comparison Onset of all DVs.
	Proportion correct: significantly higher in on-time trials than early and late trials. 
        Proportion short: significantly higher in early trials than on-time trials; significantly higher    
        in on-time trials than late trials.  
	Point of subjective equality: significantly longer in early trials than on-time trials;    
        significantly longer in on-time trials than late trials.  
2. At middle delay length, unknown if effect of Comparison Onset of all DVs.
3. At longest delay length, no effect of Comparison Onset of all DVs.

q20.value: We follow Macmillan and Creelman (1991, pp. 219–220) to calculate the points of subjective equality (PSE) from proportion short for each participant in each condition. The PSE is the time interval subjectively considered as equally long as the standard interval, as operationalized by being judged as shorter 50% of the time. We will first transform the proportions of responding “short” for each of the six comparison intervals to z-coordinates. Since z (1.00) is positive infinity and z (0.00) is negative infinity, we converted the 100 percent probability and 0 percent probability to 1-(1/2N) and 1/2N with N as the number of trials in each condition. Then we will fit a first order (linear) polynomial function on the six z-transformed points. The intercepts of the polynomial function represent the estimated PSEs for each condition.

q21.value: We will use p-values. For ANOVA effects and interactions, the criterion is p<.05. For simple effects tests, p-values are Bonferroni-corrected.

q23.value: If a subject does not fully complete the data, including the main task and the music background questionnaire, that subject will not be included in the analysis.

attributes.title: Religious Identity and Psychological Distress After Facing Tragedy

q1.value: Religious Identity, Coping Styles, Psychological Distress, and Posttraumatic Growth Following a Natural Disaster

q2.value: Andrew Franks, Dena Abbott, Corey L. Cook

q3.value: We are collecting data from adult participants who experienced a natural disaster (tornado) to test whether (non)religiosity and (non)spirituality interact with coping style to moderate relationships between distress and post-traumatic growth following a natural disaster event.

q4.value:
We predict a moderated-mediation effect whereby the relationship between religious identity and psychological distress will be moderated by the strength of the religious identity and mediated by coping style. We predict that Christians and atheists who are stronger in their convictions will experience less psychological distress than their less devout counterparts. We also predict that the four groups will show differences in their coping styles, with the strong Christians and atheists engaging in more effective strategies that enhance their resilience to psychological distress, predicting increased posttraumatic growth. 

Exploratory analyses will be conducted on how traumatic experiences affect changes in god-belief.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We will use the SPSS Process Macro to run alternative models testing for Intensity of event as a predictor (X) of Distress and Post-traumatic growth (Y), through coping style (mediator), with Nonreligiosity (NR) and Nonspirituality as a moderating variables of these effects.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value: Data is already in collection due to the time-sensitive nature of measuring participants' experiences related to the natural disaster. The data have not been assessed and no analyses were conducted prior to pre-registration of the project.

question.value: Participants are adult residents of Ruston, LA who experienced a specific tornado event in 2019. Participants were recruited via flyers or by email invitation and were provided a hyperlink for a Qualtrics survey.

q13.value: We will recruit a minimum of 100 participants to allow for adequate power for testing relationships between variables; our sample size may be limited because it is restricted to participants who experienced the natural disaster. The PROCESS macro will use bootstrapping to estimate confidence intervals given our final available sample size.

q14.value: Our sample size may be limited because it is restricted to participants who experienced the natural disaster.

q15.value: We hope to achieve a sample of at least 100 usable participants. We will continue data collection beyond this if we are able to gain more participants. We will make the decision to complete data collection when it appears we are not gaining additional respondents following recruitment efforts.

question.value: Key variables are religiosity/spirituality (assessed using the Nonreligious-Nonspiritual Scale; NRNSS), Brief Cope Inventory, Posttraumatic Growth Inventory, and Depression Scale.

We will use the SPSS Process Macro to run alternative moderated mediation models testing for Intensity of event as a predictor (X) of Distress and Post-traumatic growth (Y), through coping style (M), with Nonreligiosity (NR) and Nonspirituality as a moderating variables (W) of these effects.

q20.value: The PROCESS Macro uses bootstrapping to estimate confidence intervals for all variables and will produce standardized estimates of all effects.

q21.value: We will use p values at the .05 level of significance, coupled with bootsrapped confidence intervals (10,000 estimations), and standardized effects sizes (Beta) in estimating effects.

q22.value: There are no awareness checks. Participants are directly asked at the start of the study to indicate that they experienced the tornado event and are asked to consider their stress levels in response to the event. All participants who indicate that they experienced the event, and who complete all necessary measures in the model, will be included in the data analysis.

q23.value: Participants who do not complete the necessary variables for each model will not be included in the model estimate. Participants who indicated that they did not experience the event, or who did not continue the survey until completion (i.e., quit at some point before the debriefing) will not be included in the data analysis.

We predict a moderated-mediation effect whereby the relationship between religious identity and psychological distress will be moderated by the strength of the religious identity and mediated by coping style. We predict that Christians and atheists who are stronger in their convictions will experience less psychological distress than their less devout counterparts. We also predict that the four groups will show differences in their coping styles, with the strong Christians and atheists engaging in more effective strategies that enhance their resilience to psychological distress, predicting increased posttraumatic growth. 

Exploratory analyses will be conducted on how traumatic experiences affect changes in god-belief.

attributes.title: Extending the Nomological Net of Emotion Differentiation to Affect Intensity, Variability, and Reactivity
attributes.description: This project will examine the associations between negative and positive emotion differentiation with negative and positive affect intensity, variability, and reactivity in daily life in four independent samples. Three samples completed 7 or 14 days of experience sampling of affect, cognition, and behavior. One sample completed daily diaries over 7 days assessing affect, cognition, and behavior.

q1.value: Extending the Nomological Net of Negative and Positive Emotion Differentiation to Affect Intensity, Variability, and Reactivity

q2.value: Sarah Havens Sperry, Nathaniel Eckland, Thomas Kwapil

q3.value:
Emotion differentiation (ED) refers to the extent to which one is able to distinguish between fine-grained aspects of emotions both at the level of valence and arousal (Barrett, Gross, Christensen, & Benbenuto, 2001) such that an individual high in ED would be able to make distinctions about their emotions in the moment (Kashdan, Ferssiszidis, Collins, & Muraven, 2010; Tugade, Frederickson, & Barrett, 2004). 

Negative emotion differentiation (NED) has been linked to various forms of psychopathology and emotion outcomes. Low NED has been linked to depression, autism spectrum disorders, aggression, alcohol use disorders, and social anxiety disorder (see Smidt & Suvak, 2015 for a review). Across numerous samples and studies, low NED has been linked to heightened negative affect (NA) intensity (Boden, Thompson, Dizén, Berenbaum, & Baker, 2013; Erbas et al., 2019; Erbas, Ceulemans, Lee Pe, Koval, & Kuppens, 2014) and stronger reactivity to daily negative events and experiences (Boden et al., 2013; Starr, Hershenberg, Li, & Shaw, 2017). Importantly, interventions aimed at improving NED such as mindfulness and emotional awareness training prove promising for reducing negative outcomes and improving well-being and adaptive emotion regulation (Kashdan, Barrett, & McKnight, 2015; Van der Gucht et al., 2019). 

Positive emotion differentiation (PED) has been understudied compared to NED. This is likely due to several preliminary findings that failed to find a significant link between PED and depression. However, PED may be linked to coping skills (Tugade, Fredrickson, & Feldman Barrett, 2004). Specifically, those with high PED are more likely to be attentive to their affective responses and the situations that elicited them, are more likely to take time to choose adaptive coping strategies and are less likely to respond spontaneously or impulsively. Furthermore, Smidt & Suvak (2015) reported that higher PED was associated with less endorsement of alcohol related problems. Lastly, higher PED has been associated with less affect intensity and variability at state and trait levels (Boden et al., 2013; Demiralp et al., 2012). Lastly, Starr et al. (2017) reported that low PED was associated with less PA reactivity to positive experiences. 

The current study aimed to examine the association of NED and PED with NA and PA intensity, variability, and reactivity in daily life in several diverse undergraduate samples. We aimed to do so in three independent samples that completed experience sampling methodology (ESM) protocols assessing momentary affect, stress, and experiences and in one sample that completed daily diary studies of affect, stress, and experiences. We included both ESM and daily diary studies in an effort to examine whether these relationships are dependent on timescale of measurement.

q4.value:
Predicted effect sizes are presented for bivariate relations: 

NED Hypotheses 
H1:  NED will be inversely associated with NA intensity (small/medium effect) 
H2: NED will be inversely associated with NA variability (large effect) 
H3: NED will moderate stress reactivity in daily life. Specifically, we hypothesize that the association of stress and NA will be stronger as the level of NED decreases. 

PED Hypotheses
H4: PED will be inversely associated with NA intensity (small/medium effect) and PA intensity (medium effect) 
H5: PED will be inversely associated with PA variability (large effect) 
H6:  PED will moderate reactivity in daily life. Specifically, we hypothesize that the association of positive experiences and PA will be stronger as the level of PED decreases 

Overall, we predict that NED and PED will be positively correlated (medium effect; H7).

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
S1: Cross-sectional, self-report measures at baseline and a 7-day ambulatory assessment protocol consisting of randomly initiated prompts (8/day).

S2: Cross-sectional, self-report measures at baseline and a 7-day ambulatory assessment protocol consisting of randomly initiated prompts (8/day).

S3: Cross-sectional, self-report measures at baseline and a 14-day ambulatory assessment protocol consisting of randomly initiated prompts (8/day).

S4: Cross-sectional, self-report measures at baseline and a 7-day daily diary study in which participants completed one prompt per day.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value:
S1: The data used in sample 1 come from a study of bipolar spectrum psychopathology and impulsivity conducted by the first author (SHS) and supervised by the senior author (TRK). Two publications resulted from this sample (Sperry & Kwapil, 2017; Sperry, Lynam, & Kwapil, 2018); however, no related analyses have been conducted related to the present goals. We have yet to calculate emotion differentiation values or affect variability in this sample and thus are blind to any descriptive characteristics related to the variables included in the present study. 

S2: The data used in sample 2 come from a study of affective dynamics in an unselected college student sample conducted by the first author (SHS) and supervised by the senior author (TRK). One publication (Sperry & Kwapil, 2019a) examined the association of bipolar spectrum psychopathology, as measured by the Hypomanic Personality Scale, with affect intensity, variability, instability, and inertia in daily life. Thus, descriptive statistics and inter-correlations of NA and PA intensity and variability are known prior to pre-registration. A second manuscript is currently under revision that examines state-trait models of affect intensity and variability between the Affect Intensity Measure and Affective Lability Scale with ESM measures of intensity and lability (Sperry & Kwapil, 2019c). Importantly, we have yet to calculate emotion differentiation values in this data set and thus are blind to the results of any analyses proposed in the present pre-registration.

S3: The data used in sample 3 come from a study of affective dynamics in a college sample oversampled for bipolar spectrum psychopathology conducted by the first author (SHS) and supervised by the senior author (TRK). Several publications are currently under review or under revision with this data set: 
1: We examined associations between bipolar spectrum psychopathology, as measured by the Hypomanic Personality Scale, with affect variability, instability, and inertia across multiple timescales (within-day, between-day; (Sperry & Kwapil, 2019b). We did not examine NED or PED in this manuscript.
2: We examined the extent to which trait emotional awareness (emotional clarity and attention to emotion) moderated and mediated the association between bipolar spectrum psychopathology and affect intensity and instability in daily life (Sperry & Kwapil, 2019d). We did not examine NED or PED in this manuscript. 
3: We examined typologies, or emotion processing styles, and whether they had differential patterns of affective dynamics in daily life (Sperry & Eckland, under review). We did not examine NED or PED in this manuscript.

Based on the pre-registration of the parent study (DOI 10.17605/OSF.IO/XJNFD), we did calculate emotion differentiation (called granularity in initial pre-registration) values for NA and PA as we hypothesized that those high on the HPS would have lower NA and PA granularity (Hypothesis 2.1). Furthermore, we hypothesized that low granularity would moderate the association of bipolar spectrum psychopathology and reactivity (Hypothesis 2.4). Thus, we are aware of descriptive statistics for NED and PED in this sample prior to this pre-registration. Furthermore, in examining hypothesis 2.4 from the parent study, we observed that both low NED and PED were associated with greater emotion reactivity in daily life. 

S4: No papers have been published using the data from sample 4. An accepted poster and paper (Castro, Eckland, Sperry, & Berenbaum, in prep), have examined associations between baseline measures of depression and worry with emotion differentiation, intensity, and frequency in daily life. We have not examined and do not plan to examine the inter-relationships between emotion differentiation, intensity, and frequency as a part of that paper. Further, intensity and frequency are measured at the level of the item (i.e, using specific emotions) rather than being aggregated into positive and negative affect. One other paper is in preparation from these data (Sperry & Eckland, in prep), examining bi-directional associations between stress and alcohol use in a subset of participants (n = 273). The only overlapping measures are intensity of positive and negative affect. There are no overlapping analyses.

question.value:
S1 (n=222)

Participants. Participants were enrolled via two methods. First, enrollment was open to any students who were currently enrolled in general psychology courses at University of North Carolina at Greensboro. We also recruited elevated scorers on the Hypomanic Personality Scale (HPS) or the UPPS-P Impulsive Behavior Scale. All participants who score at least 1.5 standard deviations above the mean on the HPS or any of the UPPS-P subscales in mass screening were invited to participate to ensure adequate representation of high scorers on the scales. Low scorers on the scales were also included in the contact list to ensure that experimenters were unaware of HPS and UPPS-P scores. Usable data were available for 222 of the 283 enrolled participants (71.6% female, 52.7% Caucasian, Age = 18.81, SD = 3.19).  Participants were dropped for endorsing more than 2 infrequency items while completing self-report questionnaires (n = 10) or for having problematic ESM protocols (n=51). Note that participants were dropped if they completed less than 15 ESM surveys or when they had an excess of invalid ESM protocols (variance associated with responding < - 1.5 SD below the mean). In addition to course credit, participants who completed at least 70% of the ESM questionnaires were entered into a drawing each semester for $100 gift cards.

Procedures. Participants attended a one-hour information session in which they completed self-report questionnaires of personality and psychopathology. After completing self-report questionnaires, research assistants described the procedures for the ESM study and participants completed a practice ESM questionnaire. Participants completed ESM surveys on their personal smartphones through two methods. The initial 69 participants were notified via text message to complete the ESM surveys using the UNCG Qualtrics system. Their cellphones signaled them and administered and time-stamped the ESM questionnaires and their responses were uploaded to Qualtrics. The remaining 153 participants completed the ESM questionnaires through an ESM application, MetricWire (Trafford, 2015), which was downloaded on participants’ phones during the information session. The MetricWire app administered questionnaires and uploaded results to their server. Both methods signaled participants eight times daily between noon and midnight for 7 days to complete the same questionnaire. 
Participants were told that they must begin the surveys within 5 minutes of the signal, after which the link expired (Qualtrics) or the survey disappeared (MetricWire), ensuring that participants did not skip questionnaires and complete them at a later time. The ESM questionnaires required approximately two minutes to complete. Participants returned to the lab for one follow-up session mid-way through their participation to ensure appropriate practices and to troubleshoot any problems.

S2 (n = 135) 

Participants. Non-clinically ascertained young adults (n = 147) enrolled in the study via an online course-credit portal for students in general psychology courses at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. Usable data were available for 135 participants. Participants were dropped due to invalid questionnaires (n=4), completing less than 15 ESM protocols (n=5), and variance of their ESM response less than -1.75 SD below the mean (n=3) indicating invalid ESM responding. Demographic characteristics for the full and final samples did not differ. The final sample was representative of the racial and ethnic background of the psychology department at the host university as well as other large public universities in the United States (59% female, 46% Caucasian, Age = 18.44, SD = 8.09. This study was approved by the UIUC IRB and participants provided informed consent. 

Procedures. Participants attended an information session during which they downloaded Metricwire on their smartphone, completed self-report questionnaires, were trained on ESM procedures, and completed a practice ESM survey that was not included in the final data. Participants were notified to complete ESM surveys 8 times daily between noon and midnight for seven and a half days at stratified random intervals (randomized within eight, 90-minute blocks). Participants had five minutes to respond, after which the ESM survey was no longer available. Participants came to the lab once during the week to encourage adequate responding.   

S3 (n=233)

Participants. A total of 352 undergraduate students were enrolled into the study via two methods. First, any participants in the course-credit subject pool were able to sign up for the study. Second, participants who scored at least 1.5 standard deviations above the mean on the HPS screening items that were included in the departmental pre-screening questionnaire were invited to participate. This recruitment method has been successfully used before to ensure adequate inclusion of high scoring participants. Undergraduates have been widely used in studies of bipolar spectrum psychopathology and are appropriate in that they are just entering into the period of greatest risk for developing bipolar disorders. Additionally, college students with elevated scores on the HPS report bipolar symptoms and have elevated risk for bipolar disorders (Kwapil et al., 2000; Walsh et al., 2015). The final sample included 233 participants with usable data. Participants were excluded from analyses (n = 119) due to technical difficulties with ESM data collection (n = 49), too few ESM questionnaires (<20 per week; n = 61), withdrawal due to time constraints (n = 5), and invalid responding (n = 4). Exclusion criteria regarding number of completed ESM questionnaires was based on two factors. First, the Hox ratio defines adequate power to detect intraindividual variability as at least 20 observations nested within the individual (Hox, 2002). Importantly, planned missing-data monte carlo simulations show minimal bias on parameter estimates at the floor of 20 questionnaires (Silvia, Kwapil, Walsh, & Myin-Germeys, 2014). Second, in order to compute indices of instability, it is important to have enough ESM questionnaires per day to adequately assess successive differences. Note that there was a larger rate of exclusions than proposed in the initial pre-registration . Participants received course credit and those who completed at least 70% of the ESM questionnaires were entered into a drawing for a $100 gift card. The study was approved by the Institutional Review Board and all participants signed informed consent. 

Procedures. Participants first completed a one-hour information session during which they were administered the self-report questionnaires and instructed on ESM procedures using either the ESM application Metricwire or Expimetrics on their smartphone. Participants completed a full practice trial before leaving the lab (not included in analyses). We switched from Metricwire to Expimetrics mid-study; however, participants’ experience of completing surveys on Metricwire and Expimetrics was largely identical. Participants completed ESM questionnaires for 14 days in their normal daily environment. They were prompted eight times daily between 10am and 10pm at random times within stratified 90 minutes intervals. Participants were instructed to begin the surveys within 10 minutes of the signal, after which the link to the survey expired, ensuring that participants could not skip questionnaires and complete them later. The ESM questionnaire required approximately two minutes to complete. Participants returned to the lab for two follow-up sessions, mid-way through each week of participation. These follow-up sessions are a standard part of our procedures and are included to motivate participation, ensure appropriate practices, and troubleshoot problems. 


S4 (n = 362)

Participants. Participants were 362 undergraduate students (70.2% female) who were recruited from a large Midwestern university. Their average age was 19 (SD=1.3). The sample was 50.3% White, 30.9% Asian or Asian-American, 13.5% Latino/Hispanic, 5.8% African-American, and 13% other or multiracial. All participants individually consented to be a part of the study and were compensated with course credit.
Procedures. Participants attended a 15-minute lab session in which they completed self-report measures. Following the competition of the self-reports, a research assistant explained the daily diaries to participants and walked them through a daily survey. Participants were given the opportunity to ask clarification questions about any of the items on the daily survey before leaving the lab. Starting the day after their lab session, the participants received a survey at 9 pm via email, sent through Qualtrics, each night for seven nights.

q13.value:
S1 (n=222)

Power. Determination of power and sample sizes in multilevel designs is considerably more complicated in part because the optimal sample size for estimating one parameter in a multilevel design may not be the optimal sample size for estimating a different parameter (Snijders & Bosker, 1999). Hox (2002) advocates the “50/20” rule for assessing cross-level interactions which suggested that the study should have a minimum of 20 measurements nested within a minimum of 50 participants. Each of the studies exceeded this sample size, and the protocol required that participants complete a minimum of 15 ESM questionnaires.

S2 (n = 135) 

Power. Monte Carlo Simulation is the most appropriate method for determining power and sample size in multilevel data. Post-hoc power was computed via Monte Carlo Simulation based on recommendations by Heck and Thomas (2015). Using assumed population values (produced by saving model estimates based on 135 participants), entering all parameters, and specifying 500 replications, power was estimated at .80 for examining direct effects between level 2 and level 1 measures. Additionally, using 500 replications, power was estimated to be .69 for determining cross-level interactions.  

S3 (n=233)
Power. Using 135 participants from preliminary findings (Sperry & Kwapil, 2019), we estimated two models using assumed population values (produced by saving model estimations based on pilot data), entering all parameters, and specifying 500 replications. For 135 participants with an average of 37 observations nested within person, power was estimated at 0.80 for detecting direct effects and .69 for cross-level interactions. Sample sizes for Pearson correlations and linear regressions were determined using G*Power (Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007). For a bivariate normal correlation, a sample size of 193 individuals was sufficient to detect small effects with 80% power. We calculated sample size for linear regressions based on R2 increase in a three-step model with three predictors – suggesting a sample size of 247.

S4 (n = 362)

Power. This was an exploratory study of emotions and emotion regulation in daily life. Since the goals of the study were exploratory, we made an a priori decision to collect data over two semesters.

question.value:
All momentary affect items have the item stem “Right now, I feel….” All items were answered on a scale of 1: Not at all to 7: Very much. 

Momentary Negative Affect: 
	S1: Irritable, frustrated, sad, anxious, bored
S2: Sad, bored, nervous, sluggish, angry, afraid, irritable 
S3: Sad, bored, angry, nervous, afraid, irritable, bored, sluggish
S4: Angry, anxious, sad, guilty/ashamed, bored


Momentary Positive Affect: 
	S1: Happy, energetic, confident
S2: Energetic, relaxed, enthusiastic, calm, confident
S3: Content, enthusiastic, calm, proud, determined, excited, confident
S4: Calm, content/satisfied, happy/cheerful, excited/enthusiastic, proud


Momentary Stress: 
	S1: “My current situation is stressful”
S2: “Right now my situation is stressful” 
S3: “Right now my situation is stressful”
S4: “Rate the severity of the stress [you experienced today]”


Momentary Positive Experience: 
S1: Index of: “My current situation is positive”, “Right now I am doing something exciting”, “I am successful in my current activity” 
S2: Index of: “Since the last beep, the most important think that happened was positive”, “I am successful in my current activity”
S3: Index of: “Right now my situation is pleasant”, “Right now I enjoy my current activity” 
S4: not included

Statistical models: 

NED & PED
Following Tugade et al. (2004), we will calculate the average intraclass correlations (ICCs) with absolute agreement (Shrout & Fleiss, 1979) for all NA items and all PA items over the ESM (S1 – S3)/daily diary (S4) protocols, respectively. We will then transform each ICC using a Fisher Z transformation. Finally, we will subtract the resulting score from 1 so that higher scores represented greater differentiation.   

Intensity

To measure associations between NED & PED with NA and PA intensity we will compute two mixed linear models using lme4 in R Version 3.6.1 for each sample as follows:  

Model.1 <- lmer (NAt ~ 1 + NED + (1|ID), data = SampleX) 
Model.2 <- lmer(NAt ~ 1 + PED + (1|ID), data = SampleX)
Model.3 <- lmer (PAt ~ 1 + NED + (1|ID), data = SampleX) 
Model.4 <- lmer(PAt ~ 1 + PED + (1|ID), data = SampleX)


Variability
Affective variability of NA and PA will be computed using the within person variance (WPV) which involves taking the standard deviation of an individual’s PA and NA items across the assessment period (Eid & Diener, 1999; Jahng et al., 2008). WPV will be calculated via the following formula: 
 
Importantly, it is important to control for mean level when examining associations with variability. Thus, we will examine several linear regression models in R Version 3.6.1 controlling for intensity of NA and PA: 

Model.5 <- lm(NA.WPV ~ NED + NA, data = SampleX)
Model.6 <- lm(NA.WPV ~ PED + NA, data = SampleX)
Model.7 <- lm(PA.WPV ~ NED + PA, data = SampleX)
Model.8 <- lm(PA.WPV ~ PED + PA, data = SampleX)

Reactivity
In order to assess whether PED or NED moderates daily reactivity we will run a series of mixed linear regressions in lme4. Note that we will examine stress or positive experience predicting for NA or PA at the subsequent time point, controlling for NA or PA at the previous time point. We will examine the following mixed linear regressions:  

Model.9 <- lmer (NAt+1 ~ 1 + NED + stresst + NAt + NED* stresst  + (1 + stresst |ID), data = SampleX) 

Model.10 <- lmer (NAt+1 ~ 1 + PED + stresst + NAt + PED* stresst  + (1 + stresst|ID), data = SampleX) 

Model.11 <- lmer (PAt+1~ 1 + NED + Pos.Expt + PAt + NED* Pos.Expt + (1 + Pos.Expt |ID), data = SampleX) 

Model.12 <- lmer (PA +1 ~ 1 + PED + Pos.Expt + PAt + PED* Pos.Expt + (1 + Pos.Expt |ID), data = SampleX) 


Missing data: 

All missing data will be considered missing at random

registration_responses.q3:
Emotion differentiation (ED) refers to the extent to which one is able to distinguish between fine-grained aspects of emotions both at the level of valence and arousal (Barrett, Gross, Christensen, & Benbenuto, 2001) such that an individual high in ED would be able to make distinctions about their emotions in the moment (Kashdan, Ferssiszidis, Collins, & Muraven, 2010; Tugade, Frederickson, & Barrett, 2004). 

Negative emotion differentiation (NED) has been linked to various forms of psychopathology and emotion outcomes. Low NED has been linked to depression, autism spectrum disorders, aggression, alcohol use disorders, and social anxiety disorder (see Smidt & Suvak, 2015 for a review). Across numerous samples and studies, low NED has been linked to heightened negative affect (NA) intensity (Boden, Thompson, Dizén, Berenbaum, & Baker, 2013; Erbas et al., 2019; Erbas, Ceulemans, Lee Pe, Koval, & Kuppens, 2014) and stronger reactivity to daily negative events and experiences (Boden et al., 2013; Starr, Hershenberg, Li, & Shaw, 2017). Importantly, interventions aimed at improving NED such as mindfulness and emotional awareness training prove promising for reducing negative outcomes and improving well-being and adaptive emotion regulation (Kashdan, Barrett, & McKnight, 2015; Van der Gucht et al., 2019). 

Positive emotion differentiation (PED) has been understudied compared to NED. This is likely due to several preliminary findings that failed to find a significant link between PED and depression. However, PED may be linked to coping skills (Tugade, Fredrickson, & Feldman Barrett, 2004). Specifically, those with high PED are more likely to be attentive to their affective responses and the situations that elicited them, are more likely to take time to choose adaptive coping strategies and are less likely to respond spontaneously or impulsively. Furthermore, Smidt & Suvak (2015) reported that higher PED was associated with less endorsement of alcohol related problems. Lastly, higher PED has been associated with less affect intensity and variability at state and trait levels (Boden et al., 2013; Demiralp et al., 2012). Lastly, Starr et al. (2017) reported that low PED was associated with less PA reactivity to positive experiences. 

The current study aimed to examine the association of NED and PED with NA and PA intensity, variability, and reactivity in daily life in several diverse undergraduate samples. We aimed to do so in three independent samples that completed experience sampling methodology (ESM) protocols assessing momentary affect, stress, and experiences and in one sample that completed daily diary studies of affect, stress, and experiences. We included both ESM and daily diary studies in an effort to examine whether these relationships are dependent on timescale of measurement.
registration_responses.q4:
Predicted effect sizes are presented for bivariate relations: 

NED Hypotheses 
H1:  NED will be inversely associated with NA intensity (small/medium effect) 
H2: NED will be inversely associated with NA variability (large effect) 
H3: NED will moderate stress reactivity in daily life. Specifically, we hypothesize that the association of stress and NA will be stronger as the level of NED decreases. 

PED Hypotheses
H4: PED will be inversely associated with NA intensity (small/medium effect) and PA intensity (medium effect) 
H5: PED will be inversely associated with PA variability (large effect) 
H6:  PED will moderate reactivity in daily life. Specifically, we hypothesize that the association of positive experiences and PA will be stronger as the level of PED decreases 

Overall, we predict that NED and PED will be positively correlated (medium effect; H7).

registration_responses.q11:
S1: The data used in sample 1 come from a study of bipolar spectrum psychopathology and impulsivity conducted by the first author (SHS) and supervised by the senior author (TRK). Two publications resulted from this sample (Sperry & Kwapil, 2017; Sperry, Lynam, & Kwapil, 2018); however, no related analyses have been conducted related to the present goals. We have yet to calculate emotion differentiation values or affect variability in this sample and thus are blind to any descriptive characteristics related to the variables included in the present study. 

S2: The data used in sample 2 come from a study of affective dynamics in an unselected college student sample conducted by the first author (SHS) and supervised by the senior author (TRK). One publication (Sperry & Kwapil, 2019a) examined the association of bipolar spectrum psychopathology, as measured by the Hypomanic Personality Scale, with affect intensity, variability, instability, and inertia in daily life. Thus, descriptive statistics and inter-correlations of NA and PA intensity and variability are known prior to pre-registration. A second manuscript is currently under revision that examines state-trait models of affect intensity and variability between the Affect Intensity Measure and Affective Lability Scale with ESM measures of intensity and lability (Sperry & Kwapil, 2019c). Importantly, we have yet to calculate emotion differentiation values in this data set and thus are blind to the results of any analyses proposed in the present pre-registration.

S3: The data used in sample 3 come from a study of affective dynamics in a college sample oversampled for bipolar spectrum psychopathology conducted by the first author (SHS) and supervised by the senior author (TRK). Several publications are currently under review or under revision with this data set: 
1: We examined associations between bipolar spectrum psychopathology, as measured by the Hypomanic Personality Scale, with affect variability, instability, and inertia across multiple timescales (within-day, between-day; (Sperry & Kwapil, 2019b). We did not examine NED or PED in this manuscript.
2: We examined the extent to which trait emotional awareness (emotional clarity and attention to emotion) moderated and mediated the association between bipolar spectrum psychopathology and affect intensity and instability in daily life (Sperry & Kwapil, 2019d). We did not examine NED or PED in this manuscript. 
3: We examined typologies, or emotion processing styles, and whether they had differential patterns of affective dynamics in daily life (Sperry & Eckland, under review). We did not examine NED or PED in this manuscript.

Based on the pre-registration of the parent study (DOI 10.17605/OSF.IO/XJNFD), we did calculate emotion differentiation (called granularity in initial pre-registration) values for NA and PA as we hypothesized that those high on the HPS would have lower NA and PA granularity (Hypothesis 2.1). Furthermore, we hypothesized that low granularity would moderate the association of bipolar spectrum psychopathology and reactivity (Hypothesis 2.4). Thus, we are aware of descriptive statistics for NED and PED in this sample prior to this pre-registration. Furthermore, in examining hypothesis 2.4 from the parent study, we observed that both low NED and PED were associated with greater emotion reactivity in daily life. 

S4: No papers have been published using the data from sample 4. An accepted poster and paper (Castro, Eckland, Sperry, & Berenbaum, in prep), have examined associations between baseline measures of depression and worry with emotion differentiation, intensity, and frequency in daily life. We have not examined and do not plan to examine the inter-relationships between emotion differentiation, intensity, and frequency as a part of that paper. Further, intensity and frequency are measured at the level of the item (i.e, using specific emotions) rather than being aggregated into positive and negative affect. One other paper is in preparation from these data (Sperry & Eckland, in prep), examining bi-directional associations between stress and alcohol use in a subset of participants (n = 273). The only overlapping measures are intensity of positive and negative affect. There are no overlapping analyses.
registration_responses.q13:
S1 (n=222)

Power. Determination of power and sample sizes in multilevel designs is considerably more complicated in part because the optimal sample size for estimating one parameter in a multilevel design may not be the optimal sample size for estimating a different parameter (Snijders & Bosker, 1999). Hox (2002) advocates the “50/20” rule for assessing cross-level interactions which suggested that the study should have a minimum of 20 measurements nested within a minimum of 50 participants. Each of the studies exceeded this sample size, and the protocol required that participants complete a minimum of 15 ESM questionnaires.

S2 (n = 135) 

Power. Monte Carlo Simulation is the most appropriate method for determining power and sample size in multilevel data. Post-hoc power was computed via Monte Carlo Simulation based on recommendations by Heck and Thomas (2015). Using assumed population values (produced by saving model estimates based on 135 participants), entering all parameters, and specifying 500 replications, power was estimated at .80 for examining direct effects between level 2 and level 1 measures. Additionally, using 500 replications, power was estimated to be .69 for determining cross-level interactions.  

S3 (n=233)
Power. Using 135 participants from preliminary findings (Sperry & Kwapil, 2019), we estimated two models using assumed population values (produced by saving model estimations based on pilot data), entering all parameters, and specifying 500 replications. For 135 participants with an average of 37 observations nested within person, power was estimated at 0.80 for detecting direct effects and .69 for cross-level interactions. Sample sizes for Pearson correlations and linear regressions were determined using G*Power (Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007). For a bivariate normal correlation, a sample size of 193 individuals was sufficient to detect small effects with 80% power. We calculated sample size for linear regressions based on R2 increase in a three-step model with three predictors – suggesting a sample size of 247.

S4 (n = 362)

Power. This was an exploratory study of emotions and emotion regulation in daily life. Since the goals of the study were exploratory, we made an a priori decision to collect data over two semesters.
