registration_responses.q12.question:
S1 (n=222)

Participants. Participants were enrolled via two methods. First, enrollment was open to any students who were currently enrolled in general psychology courses at University of North Carolina at Greensboro. We also recruited elevated scorers on the Hypomanic Personality Scale (HPS) or the UPPS-P Impulsive Behavior Scale. All participants who score at least 1.5 standard deviations above the mean on the HPS or any of the UPPS-P subscales in mass screening were invited to participate to ensure adequate representation of high scorers on the scales. Low scorers on the scales were also included in the contact list to ensure that experimenters were unaware of HPS and UPPS-P scores. Usable data were available for 222 of the 283 enrolled participants (71.6% female, 52.7% Caucasian, Age = 18.81, SD = 3.19).  Participants were dropped for endorsing more than 2 infrequency items while completing self-report questionnaires (n = 10) or for having problematic ESM protocols (n=51). Note that participants were dropped if they completed less than 15 ESM surveys or when they had an excess of invalid ESM protocols (variance associated with responding < - 1.5 SD below the mean). In addition to course credit, participants who completed at least 70% of the ESM questionnaires were entered into a drawing each semester for $100 gift cards.

Procedures. Participants attended a one-hour information session in which they completed self-report questionnaires of personality and psychopathology. After completing self-report questionnaires, research assistants described the procedures for the ESM study and participants completed a practice ESM questionnaire. Participants completed ESM surveys on their personal smartphones through two methods. The initial 69 participants were notified via text message to complete the ESM surveys using the UNCG Qualtrics system. Their cellphones signaled them and administered and time-stamped the ESM questionnaires and their responses were uploaded to Qualtrics. The remaining 153 participants completed the ESM questionnaires through an ESM application, MetricWire (Trafford, 2015), which was downloaded on participants’ phones during the information session. The MetricWire app administered questionnaires and uploaded results to their server. Both methods signaled participants eight times daily between noon and midnight for 7 days to complete the same questionnaire. 
Participants were told that they must begin the surveys within 5 minutes of the signal, after which the link expired (Qualtrics) or the survey disappeared (MetricWire), ensuring that participants did not skip questionnaires and complete them at a later time. The ESM questionnaires required approximately two minutes to complete. Participants returned to the lab for one follow-up session mid-way through their participation to ensure appropriate practices and to troubleshoot any problems.

S2 (n = 135) 

Participants. Non-clinically ascertained young adults (n = 147) enrolled in the study via an online course-credit portal for students in general psychology courses at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. Usable data were available for 135 participants. Participants were dropped due to invalid questionnaires (n=4), completing less than 15 ESM protocols (n=5), and variance of their ESM response less than -1.75 SD below the mean (n=3) indicating invalid ESM responding. Demographic characteristics for the full and final samples did not differ. The final sample was representative of the racial and ethnic background of the psychology department at the host university as well as other large public universities in the United States (59% female, 46% Caucasian, Age = 18.44, SD = 8.09. This study was approved by the UIUC IRB and participants provided informed consent. 

Procedures. Participants attended an information session during which they downloaded Metricwire on their smartphone, completed self-report questionnaires, were trained on ESM procedures, and completed a practice ESM survey that was not included in the final data. Participants were notified to complete ESM surveys 8 times daily between noon and midnight for seven and a half days at stratified random intervals (randomized within eight, 90-minute blocks). Participants had five minutes to respond, after which the ESM survey was no longer available. Participants came to the lab once during the week to encourage adequate responding.   

S3 (n=233)

Participants. A total of 352 undergraduate students were enrolled into the study via two methods. First, any participants in the course-credit subject pool were able to sign up for the study. Second, participants who scored at least 1.5 standard deviations above the mean on the HPS screening items that were included in the departmental pre-screening questionnaire were invited to participate. This recruitment method has been successfully used before to ensure adequate inclusion of high scoring participants. Undergraduates have been widely used in studies of bipolar spectrum psychopathology and are appropriate in that they are just entering into the period of greatest risk for developing bipolar disorders. Additionally, college students with elevated scores on the HPS report bipolar symptoms and have elevated risk for bipolar disorders (Kwapil et al., 2000; Walsh et al., 2015). The final sample included 233 participants with usable data. Participants were excluded from analyses (n = 119) due to technical difficulties with ESM data collection (n = 49), too few ESM questionnaires (<20 per week; n = 61), withdrawal due to time constraints (n = 5), and invalid responding (n = 4). Exclusion criteria regarding number of completed ESM questionnaires was based on two factors. First, the Hox ratio defines adequate power to detect intraindividual variability as at least 20 observations nested within the individual (Hox, 2002). Importantly, planned missing-data monte carlo simulations show minimal bias on parameter estimates at the floor of 20 questionnaires (Silvia, Kwapil, Walsh, & Myin-Germeys, 2014). Second, in order to compute indices of instability, it is important to have enough ESM questionnaires per day to adequately assess successive differences. Note that there was a larger rate of exclusions than proposed in the initial pre-registration . Participants received course credit and those who completed at least 70% of the ESM questionnaires were entered into a drawing for a $100 gift card. The study was approved by the Institutional Review Board and all participants signed informed consent. 

Procedures. Participants first completed a one-hour information session during which they were administered the self-report questionnaires and instructed on ESM procedures using either the ESM application Metricwire or Expimetrics on their smartphone. Participants completed a full practice trial before leaving the lab (not included in analyses). We switched from Metricwire to Expimetrics mid-study; however, participants’ experience of completing surveys on Metricwire and Expimetrics was largely identical. Participants completed ESM questionnaires for 14 days in their normal daily environment. They were prompted eight times daily between 10am and 10pm at random times within stratified 90 minutes intervals. Participants were instructed to begin the surveys within 10 minutes of the signal, after which the link to the survey expired, ensuring that participants could not skip questionnaires and complete them later. The ESM questionnaire required approximately two minutes to complete. Participants returned to the lab for two follow-up sessions, mid-way through each week of participation. These follow-up sessions are a standard part of our procedures and are included to motivate participation, ensure appropriate practices, and troubleshoot problems. 


S4 (n = 362)

Participants. Participants were 362 undergraduate students (70.2% female) who were recruited from a large Midwestern university. Their average age was 19 (SD=1.3). The sample was 50.3% White, 30.9% Asian or Asian-American, 13.5% Latino/Hispanic, 5.8% African-American, and 13% other or multiracial. All participants individually consented to be a part of the study and were compensated with course credit.
Procedures. Participants attended a 15-minute lab session in which they completed self-report measures. Following the competition of the self-reports, a research assistant explained the daily diaries to participants and walked them through a daily survey. Participants were given the opportunity to ask clarification questions about any of the items on the daily survey before leaving the lab. Starting the day after their lab session, the participants received a survey at 9 pm via email, sent through Qualtrics, each night for seven nights.

registration_responses.q19.question:
Statistical models: 

NED & PED
Following Tugade et al. (2004), we will calculate the average intraclass correlations (ICCs) with absolute agreement (Shrout & Fleiss, 1979) for all NA items and all PA items over the ESM (S1 – S3)/daily diary (S4) protocols, respectively. We will then transform each ICC using a Fisher Z transformation. Finally, we will subtract the resulting score from 1 so that higher scores represented greater differentiation.   

Intensity

To measure associations between NED & PED with NA and PA intensity we will compute two mixed linear models using lme4 in R Version 3.6.1 for each sample as follows:  

Model.1 <- lmer (NAt ~ 1 + NED + (1|ID), data = SampleX) 
Model.2 <- lmer(NAt ~ 1 + PED + (1|ID), data = SampleX)
Model.3 <- lmer (PAt ~ 1 + NED + (1|ID), data = SampleX) 
Model.4 <- lmer(PAt ~ 1 + PED + (1|ID), data = SampleX)


Variability
Affective variability of NA and PA will be computed using the within person variance (WPV) which involves taking the standard deviation of an individual’s PA and NA items across the assessment period (Eid & Diener, 1999; Jahng et al., 2008). WPV will be calculated via the following formula: 
 
Importantly, it is important to control for mean level when examining associations with variability. Thus, we will examine several linear regression models in R Version 3.6.1 controlling for intensity of NA and PA: 

Model.5 <- lm(NA.WPV ~ NED + NA, data = SampleX)
Model.6 <- lm(NA.WPV ~ PED + NA, data = SampleX)
Model.7 <- lm(PA.WPV ~ NED + PA, data = SampleX)
Model.8 <- lm(PA.WPV ~ PED + PA, data = SampleX)

Reactivity
In order to assess whether PED or NED moderates daily reactivity we will run a series of mixed linear regressions in lme4. Note that we will examine stress or positive experience predicting for NA or PA at the subsequent time point, controlling for NA or PA at the previous time point. We will examine the following mixed linear regressions:  

Model.9 <- lmer (NAt+1 ~ 1 + NED + stresst + NAt + NED* stresst  + (1 + stresst |ID), data = SampleX) 

Model.10 <- lmer (NAt+1 ~ 1 + PED + stresst + NAt + PED* stresst  + (1 + stresst|ID), data = SampleX) 

Model.11 <- lmer (PAt+1~ 1 + NED + Pos.Expt + PAt + NED* Pos.Expt + (1 + Pos.Expt |ID), data = SampleX) 

Model.12 <- lmer (PA +1 ~ 1 + PED + Pos.Expt + PAt + PED* Pos.Expt + (1 + Pos.Expt |ID), data = SampleX) 


Missing data: 

All missing data will be considered missing at random

attributes.title: What Emotion Regulation Strategies Are Related to Anxiety Symptoms? An Ecological Momentary Assessment Study.

q1.value: What Emotion Regulation Strategies Are Related to Anxiety Symptoms? An Ecological Momentary Assessment Study.

q2.value: Yasmeen T.  Alawadhi, Michele R Smith, Kevin King

q3.value: Emotion regulation is central to the development and maintenance of anxiety. Prior literature has looked at the relation between anxiety and emotion regulation largely through retrospective recall. The current study will use ecological momentary assessment (EMA) to investigate what types of emotion regulation strategies are associated with retrospective report of anxiety symptoms in a sample of undergraduate students. In other words, we hope to uncover what emotion regulation strategies are used in real time among those who are anxious (vs. those who are not). By tracking the regulation strategies used in a subject’s natural environment in their life over a period of time, we can efficiently assess how behavior and experience vary in different contexts across a specific amount of time. Using EMA is therefore critical, as it can further inform our understanding from previous research because it allows us to assess subjects in real time, thus ecological validity is maximized in collecting observations.

q4.value: Anxiety symptoms reported at baseline will be positively associated with use of maladaptive ER strategies (i.e. suppression, rumination, avoidance) in the EMA, and negatively associated with adaptive strategies including reappraisal, acceptance, and problem solving. As for distraction, there is conflicting evidence that suggests it can either be an adaptive or maladaptive strategy; depending on the context of the situation.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Sample 1: Participants (n = 159) were undergraduate students with an internet enabled smartphone at a university in the Pacific Northwest who received course credit for survey participation. Participants completed an in-lab baseline survey assessing their personality, emotion regulation and other behaviors. For analysis of trait data, we will include participants who have complete data on emotion regulation and anxiety at baseline. Participants with missing data do not differ on any demographic characteristics from those included in the current study (King, Feil, & Halvorson, 2018).  Following the in-lab baseline, participants were trained on an ecological momentary assessment protocol. Starting on a Friday, participants received 3 text messages per day (at random times during the morning, mid-day and evening) with a link to a brief web-based survey, for 10 days. Participants received surveys at least 2 hours apart and had two hours to complete each survey with 1 text message reminder for each survey. Only 5 participants (3.5%) completed fewer than 50% of EMAs; the response rate among those completing more than 50% of EMAs was 88.2%. To increase the reliability of the EMA data, we will only include data from participants who completed at least 3 full days of data collection (i.e. > 9 total EMAs) in the final analysis. 
Sample 2: The design of Sample 2 is similar to Sample 1, with the following differences. Following the in-lab baseline and EMA training, participants complete 8 days of EMAs over the course of two weekends (Thursday through Sunday). They complete 5 EMAs per day (morning, afternoon, late afternoon, evening and night), separated by at least 1 hour. Data collection is ongoing and is scheduled to be completed by March 2020. The estimated sample size for this sample is n =130.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value:
- Two-independent samples will be used for this study. Both sets of data were collected from undergraduate students in the Pacific Northwest between 2016 and 2020.
- The access to the data is restricted to lab PI and graduate students. I do not currently have access to the data.

question.value:
The participants in the study will first be completing a baseline computerized questionnaire in lab which will take them about 45 minutes to an hour to finish. 

Previous Sample: The sample  was comprised of undergraduate students from a single university in the Pacific Northwest (n=159). The undergraduate students were compensated with course credit for their participation in the study based on the number of EMA surveys they completed.  (Over the course of 10 days, three surveys were sent to participant’s internet- based smartphones at random times. The PROMIS-Anxiety scale was used to measure anxiety symptoms, and EMA survey prompts were used to assess specific ER strategies participants did or didn’t use.)
New Sample: This sample consisted of undergraduate students in the Pacific Northwest.  The undergraduate students were compensated with course credit for their participation in the study. Participants completed 8 days of cell-phone mini-surveys over the course of two weeks, starting Thursday and going to Sunday, then the next week again from Thursday to Sunday (4 days for each week, and on each day, they received 5 surveys distributed at random times). The sample size (n) for this will be finalized by the end of spring and it is estimated to be n=130 (March 2020 – cutoff date for data collection for this study)

question.value:
The measured variables include: 

Anxiety symptoms:  We used the short form of the PROMIS-Anxiety scale to measure anxiety symptoms. The PROMIS scale has very strong psychometric properties, evidence of validity in both community and clinical samples (Schalet et al., 2016), and has nationally published norms. We computed a mean score for this scale and converted it to t-scores based on published norms (available at http://healthmeasures.net).

Emotion regulation. We measured emotion regulation at the baseline interview using 36 items from the Cognitive Emotion Regulation Questionnaire (CERQ; Garnefski & Kraaij, 2006), which measures what individuals generally think when experiencing negative or unpleasant events. Each sub-scale was measured with 4 items each, with response options ranging from 1 = Almost never to 5 = Almost always. Emotion regulation strategies measured by the CERQ largely reflected reflexive or disengagement responses, including self-blame, thoughts of putting the blame for what you have experienced on yourself, other-blame, putting the blame for what you have experienced on the environment or another person, rumination, thinking about the feelings and thoughts associated with the negative event, and catastrophizing, thoughts of explicitly emphasizing the terror of what you have experienced. Engagement strategies include putting into perspective, brushing aside the seriousness of the event/emphasizing the relativity when comparing it to other events, positive refocusing, thinking about joyful or positive issues instead of thinking about the actual event, positive reappraisal, creating a positive meaning to the event in terms of personal growth, acceptance, accepting what you have experienced and resigning yourself to what has happened, refocus on planning, thinking about what steps to take and how to handle the negative event. We computed a ratio of the mean of disengagement or reflexive strategies divided by the mean of engagement emotion regulation strategies. 
Baseline self-report of emotion regulation will be used as a covariate. We will report analyses with and without baseline emotion regulation included to illustrate the effects of its shared variance on the conclusions. 

Ecological Momentary Assessment of Emotion Regulation. At each EMA, participants reported whether or not (1 = yes, 0 = no) they had engaged in any emotion regulation strategies during the assessment window (“since you woke up this morning”, “since 12pm today”, and “since 4pm today…”). We adapted single items from the Cognitive Emotion Regulation Questionnaire (described above) and added an item measuring suppression. Disengagement or reflexive strategies included rumination (“You were unable to stop thinking about how you were feeling - thoughts kept popping up in your mind.”), distraction (“You tried to keep your mind off of a problem by doing something else.”), avoidance (“You tried not to think about a problem or tried to forget all about it.”), or suppression (“You tried to control your emotions by not expressing them”). Engagement strategies included reframing (“You tried to think of a problem in a different way so it didn't seem as bad.”), acceptance (“You decided to accept a situation or problem the way it is”), problem solving (“You did something to fix a problem or thought of a way to make things better.”). 

As in our prior work, we will compute a ratio score reflecting the proportion of the sum of disengagement or reflexive strategies (rumination, distraction, avoidance or suppression) with a possible range of 0 to 4, which would mean participants reported using all four strategies 100% of the time) to the sum of engagement strategies (with a possible range of 0 to 3). We will convert each of these to a ratio by dividing the proportion score for each strategy into the sum of all strategies. For participants who report not using any emotion regulation strategies at any time point; these participants’ data will be treated as missing. As for participants who report using only disengagement or reflexive strategies or only engagement strategies. For the former, we will recode their ratio score to reflect the simple sum of disengagement or reflexive strategies (because division by zero was impossible). The score for the latter will be set to 0, reflecting no use of disengagement or reflexive strategies. 

Proposed Covariates: Signal time, Gender, Age, Observation
-How Gender will be coded: Female=1 Male=0
-How Age will be coded: measured by asking participants about their date of birth
-How Signal Time will be coded: categorical 1, 2, 3, representing morning, midday, or evening survey time, respectively. For the second sample, categories will be 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 representing morning, early afternoon, later afternoon, early evening or later evening survey time, respectively.
-How Observations will be coded: numeric 1-30 representing observations across 10 days, 3 times each day for the first sample; or for the second sample 1-40 representing observations across 8 days, 5 times each day.

The main analysis will test associations among anxiety and discrete ER strategies using generalized estimating equation (GEE) logistic regression models. We will use logistic GEEs to predict binary outcomes (such as the use of an ER strategy in a given EMA, represented by a binary outcome variable (0 = Not used, 1 = used)., and linear GEEs to predict the ratio of disengagement to engagement strategies. GEE is used to account for the nesting of observations within person and subsequent shared variance between observations. 
We will test this question in two ways. First, we will test the association of anxiety reported at baseline with each specific ER strategies reported in EMA (7 total models). We will also compute the ratio of disengagement/reflexive strategies to adaptive strategies, and test the association of anxiety with this ratio in an 8th model. 

We will use the package gee in R to fit these models. 

A basic syntax example follows:

Model.example <- gee(rumination~1+anxiety+ signal+observation+gender+age+race, 
Id = PID,
Data = data, 
na.action = na.omit,
family = ”binomial”, 
corstr = " exchangeable",
Mv = 1)

We will compare different correlation structures (exchangeable, unstructured, and autoregressive lag-1 (AR-M) ), choosing the correlation structure that minimizes model fit indices (AIC and BIC).

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining whether the GEE provided evidence for anxiety as a significant predictor for the use of any specific ER strategy (or the ratio). We will report all effects in the manuscript, and use the Benjamini-Hochberg procedure (p.adjust function in R) to correct for multiple comparisons.

q22.value:
Exclusion of anyone who does not answer the baseline anxiety symptoms questions on the surveys. 
We will exclude participants who do not complete more than 9 EMAs (i.e. 2 – 3 days), as we have concerns about the reliability and validity of drawing inferences based on such little data. 
Otherwise we will not exclude participants.

q23.value: Participants who fail to complete a sufficient number of EMA surveys will be excluded. Otherwise, GEEs can compute estimates for all participants with any EMA data, regardless of the amount of missingness.

q24.value: Does anxiety predict ER strategies only in states of higher than average negative affect (rather than any use of ER strategies)?

registration_responses.q1: What Emotion Regulation Strategies Are Related to Anxiety Symptoms? An Ecological Momentary Assessment Study.
registration_responses.q2: Yasmeen T.  Alawadhi, Michele R Smith, Kevin King
registration_responses.q3: Emotion regulation is central to the development and maintenance of anxiety. Prior literature has looked at the relation between anxiety and emotion regulation largely through retrospective recall. The current study will use ecological momentary assessment (EMA) to investigate what types of emotion regulation strategies are associated with retrospective report of anxiety symptoms in a sample of undergraduate students. In other words, we hope to uncover what emotion regulation strategies are used in real time among those who are anxious (vs. those who are not). By tracking the regulation strategies used in a subject’s natural environment in their life over a period of time, we can efficiently assess how behavior and experience vary in different contexts across a specific amount of time. Using EMA is therefore critical, as it can further inform our understanding from previous research because it allows us to assess subjects in real time, thus ecological validity is maximized in collecting observations.
registration_responses.q4: Anxiety symptoms reported at baseline will be positively associated with use of maladaptive ER strategies (i.e. suppression, rumination, avoidance) in the EMA, and negatively associated with adaptive strategies including reappraisal, acceptance, and problem solving. As for distraction, there is conflicting evidence that suggests it can either be an adaptive or maladaptive strategy; depending on the context of the situation.
registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.

registration_responses.q8.question:
Sample 1: Participants (n = 159) were undergraduate students with an internet enabled smartphone at a university in the Pacific Northwest who received course credit for survey participation. Participants completed an in-lab baseline survey assessing their personality, emotion regulation and other behaviors. For analysis of trait data, we will include participants who have complete data on emotion regulation and anxiety at baseline. Participants with missing data do not differ on any demographic characteristics from those included in the current study (King, Feil, & Halvorson, 2018).  Following the in-lab baseline, participants were trained on an ecological momentary assessment protocol. Starting on a Friday, participants received 3 text messages per day (at random times during the morning, mid-day and evening) with a link to a brief web-based survey, for 10 days. Participants received surveys at least 2 hours apart and had two hours to complete each survey with 1 text message reminder for each survey. Only 5 participants (3.5%) completed fewer than 50% of EMAs; the response rate among those completing more than 50% of EMAs was 88.2%. To increase the reliability of the EMA data, we will only include data from participants who completed at least 3 full days of data collection (i.e. > 9 total EMAs) in the final analysis. 
Sample 2: The design of Sample 2 is similar to Sample 1, with the following differences. Following the in-lab baseline and EMA training, participants complete 8 days of EMAs over the course of two weekends (Thursday through Sunday). They complete 5 EMAs per day (morning, afternoon, late afternoon, evening and night), separated by at least 1 hour. Data collection is ongoing and is scheduled to be completed by March 2020. The estimated sample size for this sample is n =130.
registration_responses.q12.question:
The participants in the study will first be completing a baseline computerized questionnaire in lab which will take them about 45 minutes to an hour to finish. 

Previous Sample: The sample  was comprised of undergraduate students from a single university in the Pacific Northwest (n=159). The undergraduate students were compensated with course credit for their participation in the study based on the number of EMA surveys they completed.  (Over the course of 10 days, three surveys were sent to participant’s internet- based smartphones at random times. The PROMIS-Anxiety scale was used to measure anxiety symptoms, and EMA survey prompts were used to assess specific ER strategies participants did or didn’t use.)
New Sample: This sample consisted of undergraduate students in the Pacific Northwest.  The undergraduate students were compensated with course credit for their participation in the study. Participants completed 8 days of cell-phone mini-surveys over the course of two weeks, starting Thursday and going to Sunday, then the next week again from Thursday to Sunday (4 days for each week, and on each day, they received 5 surveys distributed at random times). The sample size (n) for this will be finalized by the end of spring and it is estimated to be n=130 (March 2020 – cutoff date for data collection for this study)
